quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In my best year at Uber, I made about 320 or $330,000 in total compensation.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark that frames the financial tradeoff of leaving big tech for independent work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But now I am making more in compensation that I made at Uber.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A counterintuitive outcome that challenges the assumption that big tech is the ceiling for earnings.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And the difference is that now my compensation... Well, my earnings keep going up as long as the newsletter is growing, so there's no theoretical cap on this.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A scalable mental model: tie income to audience growth rather than a salary band with a fixed ceiling.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But it's very, very strange, because I felt that I was in a really privileged position, just honestly making tons of money, doing a job that I loved.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights the psychological barrier practitioners face when leaving a high-status, high-compensation role—even when the next step may be better.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Only 1% of candidates who apply get in, so you can be sure that they offer you only high quality talent.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete quality bar (1% acceptance) that sets expectations for vetting rigor when hiring engineers quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And if something ever goes wrong, lemon.io offers you a swift replacement, so that you're kind of hiring with a warranty.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable risk-reduction model for hiring: treat talent sourcing like a product with a replacement guarantee.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic clickthrough metrics, and instead use your North Star metrics like activation, retention, subscriptions, and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable experimentation guidance: optimize tests against North Star metrics rather than shallow engagement proxies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more, delivering results quickly, avoiding annoying prolonged analytics cycles, and helping you easily get to the root cause of any issue you discover.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical methodology for experimentation platforms: shorten analytics cycles and prioritize root-cause analysis, not just reporting.

quotes.topic_title: Career journey to The Pragmatic Engineer
quotes.text: I'm originally from Hungary, in Europe. I then moved to UK, which was a big step up for me in terms of just getting access to, I guess, more modern software development.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights a practical career lever: relocating to a stronger ecosystem to accelerate learning and exposure to better engineering practices.

quotes.topic_title: Career journey to The Pragmatic Engineer
quotes.text: I then moved to another startup where I was a founding engineer of a acquisition. It's a startup called Skyscanner.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A concrete example of taking high-ownership roles (founding engineer) that can compound career growth and opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Career journey to The Pragmatic Engineer
quotes.text: I feel, looking back at that part of my career, I just felt really growing all the time, just taking each step one step at a time, which gave me a lot of appreciation for all these levels.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A simple mental model for career progression: focus on continuous growth via incremental steps, building understanding across levels of scope.

quotes.topic_title: Career journey to The Pragmatic Engineer
quotes.text: And then, just as I was on this really good career path, I was on the path to being a senior engineering manager, or who knows, one day I might have had a shot of being their director of engineering as well, I decided to leave Uber.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career move: leaving a clear promotion trajectory, setting up the lesson that “best on-paper path” isn’t always best personally.

quotes.topic_title: Career journey to The Pragmatic Engineer
quotes.text: And we'll talk about it a little later in the podcast, but I didn't plan like this, but I started writing a newsletter.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Shows how impactful career pivots can emerge from unplanned experimentation rather than a fully mapped strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter scale, growth engines, and paid model
quotes.text: Just today I checked and it said 189,000 subscribers.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A concrete scale benchmark that helps practitioners calibrate what “big” looks like for a newsletter business.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter scale, growth engines, and paid model
quotes.text: I think the past 90 days has been growing with 80,000 subscribers, so it's almost a thousand people per day, which is incredible.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A specific growth-rate data point that illustrates how quickly newsletters can compound once distribution clicks.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter scale, growth engines, and paid model
quotes.text: There was a tipping point in April where the newsletter was growing... In the first about nine months of the newsletter, it got to 50,000 subscribers, and then the next five months, or six or seven months, it went up by another a hundred and something thousand subscribers.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights a “tipping point” pattern—slow early growth followed by rapid acceleration—useful for setting expectations and persistence.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter scale, growth engines, and paid model
quotes.text: This was when Substack introduced recommendations, which has been a massive growth engine, and I guess being one of the top publications, I benefited from it.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Points to platform-native distribution (recommendations) as a major growth lever practitioners can prioritize and optimize for.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter scale, growth engines, and paid model
quotes.text: I make most of my revenue from subscriptions, and I don't do sponsorships or ads in the newsletter.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A monetization strategy example that challenges the default assumption that newsletters must rely on ads/sponsorships to scale.

quotes.topic_title: Income comparison: Uber compensation vs newsletter
quotes.text: But in my best year at Uber, I made about 320 or $330,000 in total compensation.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Concrete benchmark for comparing big-tech compensation to independent creator income.

quotes.topic_title: Income comparison: Uber compensation vs newsletter
quotes.text: Someone in a similar position would've made five or 600 K in total in the U.S.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights the regional-compensation gap as a key variable when evaluating career moves.

quotes.topic_title: Income comparison: Uber compensation vs newsletter
quotes.text: But now I am making more in compensation that I made at Uber.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Counterintuitive outcome that challenges the assumption that leaving big tech always means earning less.

quotes.topic_title: Income comparison: Uber compensation vs newsletter
quotes.text: And the difference is that now my compensation, my earnings, keep going up as long as the newsletter is growing, so there's no theoretical cap on this.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A simple mental model: corporate comp is capped, while creator income scales with audience growth.

quotes.topic_title: Income comparison: Uber compensation vs newsletter
quotes.text: But this was very, very surprising and very unexpected for me.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Underscores the uncertainty and upside potential of betting on independent work.

quotes.topic_title: Why leave Uber: promise, layoffs, and autonomy
quotes.text: The way I think about this life in terms of comparing to the old job is, one, it feels instead of one boss, I have thousands of micro bosses, and one of them can fire me and many do every day, but it feels safer than at a tech job where one person can decide.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian mental model for creator work: diversified “bosses” (subscribers) can feel more secure than a single manager/org decision.

quotes.topic_title: Why leave Uber: promise, layoffs, and autonomy
quotes.text: I had a spreadsheet that I maintained for the first year of the publication, where I listed, for every article, how much did my annual revenue go up a week later.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A concrete, practitioner-friendly method for measuring content ROI by tracking revenue impact per piece.

quotes.topic_title: Why leave Uber: promise, layoffs, and autonomy
quotes.text: And the crazy thing was that, when I wrote a really good article that resonated with people, sometimes it was an article that I thought was mediocre and people still loved it [inaudible 00:12:20] it was a really good article that I put tons of work in, I saw myself getting a raise.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive feedback loop in audience-driven work: perceived effort doesn’t always predict impact, but impact can directly translate to income.

quotes.topic_title: Why leave Uber: promise, layoffs, and autonomy
quotes.text: So I told myself, if four years later Uber exits and I make a bunch of money, I owe it to myself to take a risk, because then I'll have four years of savings in my bank, which... Back then I had maybe six months of savings or something. So this was the promise to myself.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A practical risk-taking rule: tie a future liquidity event to a pre-committed career experiment, anchored by a savings runway.

quotes.topic_title: Why leave Uber: promise, layoffs, and autonomy
quotes.text: We're laying off people, we had to lay off 20% of the engineers.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A specific data point illustrating how external shocks (COVID-era layoffs) can catalyze reevaluating “corporate security.”

quotes.topic_title: Startup plan, self-publishing success, and fisherman story
quotes.text: They made about $100,000 in the first year. And I was like, "That's interesting. People are buying my books." And I self-published it through Gumroad or places where I get to keep I think 90% of the revenue, but still, this was really interesting. And I got to the point where, all right, I should now start a startup. I should do fundraising and do all that. And then I asked myself, why do I really want to do that?
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A concrete revenue datapoint plus a prompt to interrogate motivations before defaulting to the VC/startup path.

quotes.topic_title: Startup plan, self-publishing success, and fisherman story
quotes.text: And I was asking myself, all right, and then what? And I was like, after I've bought everything that I don't need, I probably want to share what I know with people, do YouTube videos and write books.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A values-based “endgame” check that challenges the assumption that more money is automatically the right goal.

quotes.topic_title: Startup plan, self-publishing success, and fisherman story
quotes.text: So it's reminding me of the story of this fisherman. There's one that goes [inaudible 00:20:08] there's the same thing of, you work really hard to do what you're doing right now.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for avoiding delayed-life planning—don’t grind for years to earn the lifestyle you already want today.

quotes.topic_title: Startup plan, self-publishing success, and fisherman story
quotes.text: And the only reason I was really hesitant to start a paid newsletter, I was thinking about doing so for at least 6 to 12 months, is I was worried about writing every single week something really, really worthwhile reading, and it's a lot of work.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights the real operational constraint of creator businesses: consistent, high-quality output cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Startup plan, self-publishing success, and fisherman story
quotes.text: So I told myself that I'll... I told my wife as well that I'll do this for six months, and I'll see what happens. If there's traction, it's great. I might have found myself a new job, basically. If not, I'll just refund people. Everyone who bought an annual subscription... I didn't tell this to people, obviously, but for six months I'm going to give it my all. It's basically like a startup.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A practical risk-management approach: time-box the experiment, define success/failure, and treat it like a startup with a clear rollback plan.

quotes.topic_title: Timeline from quitting to launching newsletter
quotes.text: It was pretty much a year, a little bit less than a year. Might have been like ten months or so, but it was a year from when I decided to leave Uber.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Gives a concrete timeline data point for how long it can take between deciding to leave a job and launching an independent project.

quotes.topic_title: Timeline from quitting to launching newsletter
quotes.text: I think this was the breaking point. This was the point where I realized that it's not a family, which is weird because it never was, but it kind of felt family-like, but it's just a corporate, and I'm just a number, and this could happen to me, I guess.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A memorable, counter-narrative reminder to base career decisions on incentives and realities—not “family” framing.

quotes.topic_title: Timeline from quitting to launching newsletter
quotes.text: What no one told me is, yes I was a manager, but I was a middle manager. I didn't have too much authority. I didn't even have budget for my team.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights a practical management reality: title changes don’t necessarily come with decision rights or resources.

quotes.topic_title: Timeline from quitting to launching newsletter
quotes.text: And the reason I wanted to do a startup is, I decided I liked being a manager, but I did not how I was not in charge and I couldn't take corporate [inaudible 00:25:12] telling us to do stuff, and then we were telling them no [inaudible 00:25:16] I don't want to do that with my people.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Connects the motivation for founding to a clear operational pain: misalignment between responsibility and control in corporate structures.

quotes.topic_title: Timeline from quitting to launching newsletter
quotes.text: We have longer notice periods in Europe, so I served a longer notice period, and then left.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Actionable planning detail for practitioners: geography and employment norms can materially affect transition timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Publishing cadence and the real work of writing
quotes.text: But it actually was pretty stressful in the beginning, because it turns out to write that post, it takes at least a few days or sometimes even longer.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Counters the assumption that a weekly newsletter is “easy” by highlighting the real time cost of quality writing.

quotes.topic_title: Publishing cadence and the real work of writing
quotes.text: Even if I only spend a day researching the stuff, it's a day researching, then I have a draft on day two. Day three I get feedback, on day four it's editing, it's almost a whole week.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Provides a practical, repeatable workflow model (research → draft → feedback → edit) that practitioners can map to their own writing cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Publishing cadence and the real work of writing
quotes.text: I put in the second newsletter I think to have a bit more pressure.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Shows a deliberate use of self-imposed deadlines as a productivity lever, even when it increases workload.

quotes.topic_title: Publishing cadence and the real work of writing
quotes.text: If you want to write a book, the easiest way is go to a publisher and sign a contract, not because of the money.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Actionable accountability strategy: create external commitment mechanisms to force consistent output.

quotes.topic_title: Publishing cadence and the real work of writing
quotes.text: But it's the pressure.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Memorable distillation of the core driver behind sustained writing: deadlines and expectations, not inspiration.

quotes.topic_title: Creating structure: deadlines, accountability, and serializing a book
quotes.text: If you want to write a book, the easiest way is go to a publisher and sign a contract, not because of the money.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Reframes publishing as an accountability mechanism rather than a financial decision.

quotes.topic_title: Creating structure: deadlines, accountability, and serializing a book
quotes.text: But it's the pressure. You absolutely should go to a publisher or have some external... Someone to hold you accountable, and then you'll get it done.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Actionable advice to create external commitments that force follow-through on big projects.

quotes.topic_title: Creating structure: deadlines, accountability, and serializing a book
quotes.text: And partially, I went down the newsletter route because I liked how every week I would have to write something, and I had this sneaky idea of, what if I wrote this book where I write some posts that will be part of the book, and then the book will just come together partially.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A practical methodology: serialize components of a larger work via recurring deadlines to reduce motivation risk.

quotes.topic_title: Creating structure: deadlines, accountability, and serializing a book
quotes.text: If you put in ways that you have to do certain things, put in constraints for the things that you need to do, and then you're going to do that.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Generalizable mental model for building systems that make progress inevitable through constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Creating structure: deadlines, accountability, and serializing a book
quotes.text: But I fixed it by telling people, "You're going to get this every week," and now I have to do it. I just have no choice.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Concrete example of using public commitments as a forcing function for consistent output.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals, or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames SOC 2 as a high-leverage gatekeeper for growth and enterprise sales, clarifying the stakes for prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable reminder that compliance can be a prerequisite to even entering enterprise conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete adoption and efficiency data point that quantifies how much of SOC 2 work can be automated.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific time-to-audit claim that helps teams estimate ROI and plan compliance timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I definitely wanted to dig into that a little bit deeper, this issue that folks in our line of work run into, which is unstructured time and having to create your own structure.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a common productivity failure mode for independent creators/operators and sets up the need for self-imposed structure.

quotes.topic_title: Focus tactics: tools, timers, and blocking distractions
quotes.text: So I find that I come up with a method, and it works for a few months, and then I need to change it because my brain just learns to work around it.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A contrarian observation that focus systems can decay over time, implying you may need to rotate tactics as your brain adapts.

quotes.topic_title: Focus tactics: tools, timers, and blocking distractions
quotes.text: One is, it's almost time for me to go home, and then I'm super focused. So when I have this external thing, and I know that there's no way [inaudible 00:37:30] I need to focus on basically the deadline. So if you have deadlines, that works.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights how externally-imposed constraints (deadlines) reliably trigger deep focus when willpower doesn’t.

quotes.topic_title: Focus tactics: tools, timers, and blocking distractions
quotes.text: So a trick I sometimes do when I'm just, I just don't feel doing anything, is I set a timer of 20 minutes, and then I say, "All right, no distractions." I have a script where I just kill... I use a [inaudible 00:37:57] host file, I just kill all LinkedIn, Twitter, Facebook, whatever sites. So I just cannot reach it.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method: combine a short timebox with hard technical blocks to remove temptation entirely.

quotes.topic_title: Focus tactics: tools, timers, and blocking distractions
quotes.text: And then in the first few minutes I'm grumbling, I'm like, "I wish I could do this, I wish I could just look at Twitter to research," but about five minutes in, there's a switch, and I'm now actually heads down and doing it. And this has been the thing that has consistently worked.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Describes a practical “activation energy” model: push through the first minutes and flow often kicks in predictably.

quotes.topic_title: Focus tactics: tools, timers, and blocking distractions
quotes.text: Yeah. And the simple thing, start a 20 minute timer, and you say, "For 20 minutes, I need to focus on this thing," on your iPhone or somewhere else. It's just 20 minutes, but during that time you cannot do anything else. And just try it. It works for me, like a charm, once I decide to actually do it.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A low-friction entry point to deep work: a short, strict commitment that’s easy to start and often snowballs into momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Upsides of newsletter life: time and experimentation
quotes.text: I really like that it forces me to have my calendar empty, because for so many years my calendar was this giant mess of meetings on top of meetings, and I would barely have any time to actually have focus time.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable shift: designing for an empty calendar to protect deep work time.

quotes.topic_title: Upsides of newsletter life: time and experimentation
quotes.text: Now I actually have the opposite. I usually have a lot of focus time, and I have very, very few meetings or things.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A concrete example of the operational upside of newsletter life: defaulting to focus time rather than meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Upsides of newsletter life: time and experimentation
quotes.text: And I also like how much in charge I am. Initially it freaked me out, in the sense of how much creative freedom I have.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that full autonomy can be psychologically challenging even when desirable.

quotes.topic_title: Upsides of newsletter life: time and experimentation
quotes.text: So these are the two favorite things, is the open calendar or very few meetings, and experimenting, trying out stuff and being able to decide what I want to try out.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A simple two-part framework for the upsides: protect time (open calendar) and run experiments (iterate formats/ideas).

quotes.topic_title: Upsides of newsletter life: time and experimentation
quotes.text: I have a rule of no meetings before 3:00 PM, and it generally works 99% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific, replicable tactic for preserving deep work blocks with a clear constraint and success rate.

quotes.topic_title: Downsides: loneliness, guilt, and creator stress
quotes.text: I have a rule of no meetings before 3:00 PM, and it generally works 99% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete scheduling rule practitioners can adopt to protect deep work time.

quotes.topic_title: Downsides: loneliness, guilt, and creator stress
quotes.text: And the reason I do that is, to your point, if there's a meeting at 11:00, I just can't do anything really deep until that point, and then afterwards I have to get back on track.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Explains the hidden cost of mid-day meetings: they fragment focus both before and after.

quotes.topic_title: Downsides: loneliness, guilt, and creator stress
quotes.text: The structure is weird, because I felt really guilty for the first few months, because I felt that at Uber I was more productive, because I had to be.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: Highlights a common solo-creator trap: equating productivity with externally imposed structure and busyness.

quotes.topic_title: Downsides: loneliness, guilt, and creator stress
quotes.text: I compensate for that by working in a shared workspace, a shared office, which is a techy workspace.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A practical tactic for reducing loneliness and restoring ambient social connection outside a company.

quotes.topic_title: Downsides: loneliness, guilt, and creator stress
quotes.text: You're all running your own business, and there is some level of competition. So you might not... Because it's a little bit of attention economy as well.
quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.context: A counterintuitive downside of creator communities: shared craft but competitive incentives can limit openness.
